direction.raw_text: A lone farmhouse sits isolated against a prairie backdrop, silhouetted by a marbled dawn sky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a gray-haired woman in her late sixties, meticulously packs a suitcase.  She picks up a small, framed
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: from a chest-of-drawers and holds it up to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a picture of a man about Marian's age.  He has a sweet natured smile on his face.  Marian looks at it longingly, then packs it carefully in her suitcase between some sweaters and closes it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A paint-chipped truck rounds the corner on a dirt road leading into the farm. Marian, waiting on the porch, ready to go, rises and waves. A FEW MOMENTS LATER - Marian's son, STEVE, dressed in jeans and flannel shirt, loads his mother's single piece of luggage into the bed of the truck, climbs back into the cab, where his mother is sitting, and drives off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: descending in the hot, cerulean sky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian, looking a little forlorn and out of sorts, stands out by the taxi area with her suitcase on a tote, looking around for a cab, unsure what to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - A FEW MINUTES LATER MISCHA, a somewhat dissolute-looking Russian cabbie in his thirties, roughhouses Marian's single piece of luggage into the dirty, cluttered trunk of his cab.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian is sitting in the back of the cab as Mischa opens the driver's side door and slams it shut, rattling Marian's nerves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian fumbles with a piece of paper she's rooted out of her purse. Mischa, annoyed, slams the shift lever into Drive and lurches off. Marian leans forward into the rectangular opening of the Plexiglas partition.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the REAR-VIEW MIRROR we glimpse Mischa giving Marian a sly look.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (brusquely) Where to?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you sure you got my bag in?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you think?  I left it on the curb?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, I'm a little nervous.  It's my first time in New York.  Just a minute.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to go to 526 East 5TH.  That's in the East Village.  My daughter said it would cost thirty dollars.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The TAXI passes on a turnpike, streaming with vehicles, headed toward Manhattan.  DRIVE-BY TRANSITION.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hurtling along.  Marian cranes her head through the partition and attempts to strike up a conversation with the surly cabbie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mischa chuckles as Marian sits back in the cab.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I came to New York to visit my youngest daughter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And where is she?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She would have come to the airport to meet me - she wanted to - but ... but, she just started a new job and, well, I guess no one drives here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So, you come here all by yourself?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh, yes.  My husband passed away recently ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ... And the children thought I should take a trip.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm from South Dakota.  Where are you from?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Moscow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ohhh.  Do you know the East Village?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yeah ... yeah ... it's a hellhole.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (disconcerted) You mean it's dangerous?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nah, not dangerous.  Not that dangerous. (beat) Not during the day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - looking out the window, her face clouded with consternation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cars pouring into Manhattan over one of the many bridges spanning the East River.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The cab brakes to a halt, bringing Marian INTO THE FRAME, her face strickened with fear. Marian climbs out of the cab as Mischa, in the background, opens the trunk to retrieve her bag.  Marian, taking in the foreign surroundings, seems confused about something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mischa closes the trunk and approaches Marian with her one piece of luggage on a tote.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Pardon me, Mischa.  Is this 526 East 5TH Street?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no.  Sorry, I can't drive you to door.  There's a roadblock on Avenue B ... (he gestures down the street) right there ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - At the far end of the block, we SEE a movable, blue NYPD roadblock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - The two of them, Marian looking puzzled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He chuckles to himself, but Marian doesn't get the joke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian unsnaps her wallet and grudgingly hands the disreputable cabbie two twenties and a five. Mischa takes the money and starts away.  Halfway back to his cab, he turns around and calls out to Marian, who stands frozen on the dilapidated street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mischa hugs an imaginary purse close to his side.  Marian apes his advice in all seriousness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mischa climbs back into his cab and peels off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is one-way street.  You go down the block to the middle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pointing uncertainly) This way?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.  Not far.  You will be fine. (beat) It's still day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see.  How much?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forty-five all total.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forty-five?  I thought it was only supposed to be thirty?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thirty is base price.  Tolls, tax, tip ... it all adds up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, lady. (Marian turns) Hold purse like this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nodding approval) Good luck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: of Marian standing forlornly at the end of the street, a Dayton's shopping bag in one hand, her luggage strapped to the tote in the other.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: MY MOTHER DREAMS THE SATAN'S DISCIPLES IN NEW YORK CUT TO

direction.raw_text: DAY - A FEW MINUTES LATER Marian pulling her luggage apprehensively down the street. She passes THE SQUATTERS, a motley group of homeless teenagers, pierced, tattooed, wild hairdos and even wilder attire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian, shocked by their circumstances, rolls her luggage past them, smiling faintly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian continues on.  She's distracted by ...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: #1 Hey, lady, can you help us out with some change today?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 Come on.  Every little bit helps.  A little food, you know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe some other time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 Thanks a lot anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: in her thirties, who looks like she hasn't slept in a week, bent over the railing of a second-story fire escape balcony, in the throes of a veritable rage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian stares up at her, even more disconcerted than ever. The enraged woman continues her tirade at an unseen old boyfriend below.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian looks away and, intrepid Midwesterner that she is, pushes on.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You forgot your fucking plant, you fucking asshole!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And there's a lot of other shit in there you forgot.  Just wait there, I'm going to go fucking get it for you, all right? No, just wait there! Do you want me to go get it for you?  Well, why don't I just do that, huh?  I'm going to do that right now!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: dressed strangely, stands surreally in the middle of the street, blowing huge clouds of cigarette smoke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: parade past, laughing hysterically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of unmufflered, chrome-coruscating HARLEYS round the corner in a ear-shattering approach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - stops dead in her tracks and stares in heartstopping terror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - The BIKERS, wearing their club's colors embroidered on blue jeans, and leather, vests, back their motorcycles in a uniform row against the curb, kill their engines, park them at an angle on their kickstands, and dismount. They high-five a biker known as the DISCIPLE PROSPECT, a small, mean-looking man with a red bandana tied taut over his head, and then disappear into the windowless clubhouse, passing through a large, forbidding, black door with the skeleton of Death riding a motorcycle painted on it. The Disciple Prospect tosses the butt of a cigarette into a rusted steel drum and flames erupt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - in horror, cannot pry her eyes away from them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - An upstairs window on a six-story, red-brick co-op building. PAULA, Marian's daughter, a pretty woman with short dark hair, is leaning out the window, waving.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mom!  Hi!  I'll be right down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Paula emerges to greet her mother. Marian glances one last time across the street and exchanges oblique looks with the Disciple Prospect, now parked on a stool next to the burning drum.  He seems to home in on her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A nice, one-bedroom co-op, tastefully furnished.  Paula is unpacking Marian's things.  Marian stands in the middle of the apartment, feeling relaxed, if still a bit shaken, for the first time since she arrived.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian walks over to the window and peers out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian returns her gaze to the view out the window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So, what do you think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, once you're inside, it's nice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't like where I live?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, when I walked up the block, I ... well, my word!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's New York.  It looks rundown, but it's safe during the day.  You'll get used to it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - Out the window.  Two BIKERS stand with their arms crisscrossed against their leather-vested chests, framing the burning drum on the sidewalk, guarding the phalanx of Harleys.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - LATER Paula and Marian are sitting at the dining table.  They're studying one of those plastic laminated maps of New York that you can buy everywhere.  Paula is attempting to acquaint her mother with Manhattan's complex public transportation system.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian removes her glasses and fixes her gaze on her daughter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You take the M-15 bus all the way to ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Street.  And then you take the crosstown bus to 5TH Avenue, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art is right there.  You can't miss it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wanted to ask you something.  Those motorcycles across the street ...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh-huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ... What are they all doing there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's the Satan's Disciples' New York headquarters.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (alarmed) The motorcycle gang?  Don't they deal drugs and rape young girls?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've never had any problem with them. People say it's the safest block in the East Village. (lays a reassuring hand on her mother's arm) I just hope their motorcycles don't keep you up at night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: UP to Marian lying wide awake on a convertible sofa next to the street window.  We (Marian!) hear VOICES, MOTORCYCLES REVVING, POLICE SIRENS, followed by what sounds like GUNFIRE, tires SCREECHING, a cacophony of sounds typical of summer nights in the East Village. We go UP and OVER Marian toward the window as imaginary voices flood in and become intelligible.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Did that shipment of heroin come in? That old lady see them? We can kill her if we have to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: erupts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MONTAGE A Kenneth Anger Scorpio Rising-like MONTAGE: A black-booted foot kick-starts a Harley. A gleaming chrome exhaust pipe vibrates and spits smoke. A black-gloved hand revs a handle-bar accelerator. A helmet is pulled down over a Hun-like face. Flames roar in the steel drum as though a signpost in Hell. One of the DISCIPLES, bare-chested, long-haired, sweating, swings a baseball bat and calls out to Marian in a singsong voice:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another half-naked BIKER, arms tattooed up and down, has Marian's suitcase open and is scattering her belongings out into the street.  He finds the framed photo of her deceased husband and tosses it to the pavement.  He raises his head slowly with a sneer and looks up at ...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Marian ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - standing in the window in her nightgown, a hand covering her mouth, looking down in utter terror on the fire-lit tableaux of her nightmare.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - starts stomping on the photo with the heel of his boot, shattering the glass.  Then he removes the photo from the frame and slowly drops it into the roaring conflagration in the oil drum. The other dawdling Disciples guffaw loudly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian wakes with a start, consciousness giving way to a sigh of relief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of Paula's red-brick co-op, splashed with sunlight and framed by a bright blue sky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's quiet in the co-op.  Marian is dusting the bookshelves and humming to herself. Behind a shelf of books she discovers a PHOTO ENVELOPE with some snapshots in them.  Curious, she has a look-see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - flipping through Marian's hands.  They chronicle Paula and a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on a recent vacation to a Caribbean island.  Marian is amused by them ... until she comes to one showing Paula with her bathing suit top off, arms raised giddily in the air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - gasps, then blushes and quickly replaces the pictures.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - LATER Marian is at the window, peering through the furling curtains.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - MARIAN'S P.O.V. - Looking down on the Satan's Disciples' clubhouse.  Two BIKERS and their GIRLFRIENDS swagger out of the clubhouse, don their helmets, mount their bikes, kick-start them to life and roar off down the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - draws away from the window.  She picks up her "Streetwise Manhattan" laminated map, puts her glasses on, looks at it, debating whether to tackle the streets of New York or not. A FEW MINUTES LATER - Marian, determined now to get out of the co-op, pulls her purse over her shoulder and grips it like the cabbie instructed.  Then she moves to the front door, opens it, and steps warily out into the hallway.  She freezes when she
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian cowers against the half-open door as a young MAN, wearing faded jeans, black cowboy boots, and leather vest over a naked torso, comes charging down the stairs pulled by a frothing, pent-up BULLDOG on a leash. As he passes, Marian retreats quickly back into her unit, closes the door, and locks the locks from inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paula is hanging up her coat and setting down her briefcase, an incredulous expression on her face, looking at ... Marian, sitting in a chair by the window, leafing through a magazine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian shrugs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (mildly rebuking) You didn't leave the house all day?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Manhattan skyscrapers framed against a twilit sky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian and Paula are sitting at the bar.  They each have a glass of white wine in front of them.  Paula is looking at some PHOTOS of the farm that Marian has brought along.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paula continues to browse through the snaps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian removes a pill from a small vial she's rummaged out of her purse and slips it discreetly into her mouth.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Would you look at those strawberries. They made the best jam. (passes Paula the photos) Here are some more pictures of the farm. Crops were unbelievable this year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Plenty of rain.  Your dad would have been happy with that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just can't seem to focus on anything these days.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning to her mother) That's why it's good you came to visit me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (washing her pill down with some wine) How are you doing sweetheart?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dating anyone?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I'm working too much, I don't have time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about the fellow in those pictures?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What pictures?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know ... (raises both hands in the air) ... whoops!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (blushing) Mother!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, they were right out in plain view.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Behind the books.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I was dusting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reluctantly explaining) I was seeing Aaron and there were some ... complications.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He seemed quite taken with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want to talk about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hurt) You know, you never tell me anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's not true. (lays a placating hand on her mother's arm) Besides, I don't want you dusting.  I want you to see New York.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Marian and Paula, arm-in-arm, walk down the block back to her building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: rounds the corner, slows to a crawl, and one of the Satan's Disciples stares over at the two of them as if casing them out.  Paula won't look at him, but Marian can't avert her gaze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian lying awake in bed, the ENGINES of the Disciples' Harleys deafening ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a line of idling Harleys, the bikers, one at a time in succession, switching their single-beam headlights on. PAN ACROSS the FACES of the Disciples, mounted on their cycles, dark helmets, faded blue jeans jackets embroidered with elaborate stitching of their club's insignia, cigarettes dangling from their hirsute mouths, baleful-looking countenances, revving their engines loudly, tauntingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - From across the street, Marian, appearing like an apparition in her nightgown, surreally walks toward them, a beseeching look on her face.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me.  Could you please turn your motorcycles off?  They're so loud, I can't sleep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as the BIKERS, some ten in number, slowly approach the frail-looking Marian.  Gently, they pick her up off the ground and raise her aloft.  Then, like some moving human bier, they carry her through the forbidding black door into their clubhouse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We follow Marian down a dark corridor leading into the bowels of the clubhouse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At the end of another corridor, a MAN stands, silhouetted against an explosion of blue light.  As we near the ghostly figure, we REALIZE it's Marian's deceased husband. There's a GUN SHOT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian wakes with a start, clutching a hand to her breast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian shakes a Valium out of a vial, puts it into her mouth, swallows it with a drink of orange juice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian, not wanting to be a disappointment to her daughter, damn her fears, gathers her purse up and starts out the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian is again prevented from an easy exit when a young, hip looking COUPLE come bounding down the stairs.  As she stands at her open door to let them pass, they completely ignore her as if she didn't exist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - A FEW MOMENTS LATER Seen from Marian's perspective across the street, the front of the Satan's Disciples headquarters is quiet.  There are only a couple Harleys parked out front. Marian, relieved that there are no bikers out, hurries off in the direction of First Avenue, determined to see the sights of the city.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - MONTAGE A giddy, almost dreamlike, MONTAGE of Marian touring New York.  She's SUPERIMPOSED over famous landmarks, as if she were standing stationery and the city were in a diorama rotating all around her.  The Empire State Building; Circle Cruise Line; eating a hot dog from a street vendor; shopping at Macy's.  Marian beams as she is magically whisked along, walking on air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian comes INTO THE FRAME around the corner.  She has a spring in her step and a broad smile emblazoning her face. But her sanguine mood is quickly shattered when she HEARS shouting.  She freezes in her tracks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - THE SATAN'S DISCIPLES HEADQUARTERS - The Disciple Prospect and another Biker are roughing up a teenage KID, wrestling him into submission.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You're just chilling, huh?  Not on this block, do you understand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - at the security door of Paula's building.  She rummages anxiously through her purse, but she can't find her keys!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian glances across the street, her face tensed with fear.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, no.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - The Bikers continue to roughhouse the Kid.  The Disciple Prospect brandishes a plastic bag under his nose.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's this, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I ain't got shit on me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is that?   You're chilling, man? Well, then maybe we need to warm things up for you, man.  How many times do we got to tell you?  You don't listen and you don't learn and that's the problem. That is the problem.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - turns away from the escalating violence across the street and punches one of the buttons on the intercom.  A WOMAN'S VOICE crackles over it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's no answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian returns her frightened gaze to the altercation across the street.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Hello?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My daughter lives here and I'm her mother and I've lost my keys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello?  Hello?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - MARIAN'S P.O.V. Two more DISCIPLES emerge from the clubhouse.  One of them squirts lighter fluid on the fire burning in the steel drum and the flames explode.  Then KID is dragged over toward the fire.  The Disciple Prospect drags him dangerously close to the flames.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Roast him!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (screaming) All right all right all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - petrified, as if she'd stepped into a re-enactment of a passage out of Revelations, walks briskly down to the middle of the block toward a pay phone. DISCIPLES CLUBHOUSE - The Disciples kick the drug-dealing Teenager a couple more times, then set him free, laughing as he flees down the block in mortal fear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - Marian drops the appropriate coins in the coin slot and dials a number from memory.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian hangs up the phone and turns, quails in terror.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (quavery voice) Yes, is Paula there? ... Could you leave her a message, please?  Tell her it's urgent. (gathers herself) Her mother has lost her keys and is stranded on the street with the Satan's Disciples ... When she comes back, would you tell her to come home as quickly as she can? ... Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - The Disciple Prospect is towering over her, staring down at her with a scowl on his face.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, please, don't hurt me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just need to use the phone, lady.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, let me get out of your way then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What happened?  Did you lose your keys?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (withdrawing anxiously) Have a nice day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - Marian walks quickly ACROSS THE FRAME.  As she EXITS RIGHT, the Disciple Prospect ENTERS LEFT and trails after her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - A FEW MOMENTS LATER Marian is at the front entrance, uncertain what to do.  She quailss when the Disciple Prospect approaches.  Without a word, he reaches his arm over her and presses a buzzer to one of the units.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The DOOR BUZZES almost at once, and the Disciple Prospect pushes it in and holds it open until Marian is safely inside. He looks at her a little annoyed.  Marian is absolutely nonplussed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Hello.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Washing machine repairman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Paula comes running up the stairs.  She stops when she SEES:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - sitting on the floor, propped against the door to their unit. Paula shakes her head reprovingly at her mother who just shrugs, chagrined.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - LATER Paula is in the bathroom.  She has her mother's vial of Valium in her hand.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe you should lay low tomorrow.  I'm going to see if I can get off early and maybe we can take the ferry cruise. Okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - Marian is standing at the window looking down on the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MARIAN'S P.O.V. The Disciples are backing their bikes against the curb, parking them, and filing into the clubhouse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - Paula dispenses the remaining pills into the palm of her hand.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to herself) Three left.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - Marian looking apprehensively down at the Disciples' headquarters, stupefied. Paula emerges from the bathroom in the background.  Marian doesn't turn to acknowledge her.  She continues to stare transfixed at the bikes and the fire-burning oil drum.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian doesn't answer. Paula stands some distance from her distracted mother, a worried expression featured on her face.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (softer) Okay?  Does that sound like a plan?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Looking through the security eyepiece, a FISH-EYE LENS SHOT of an attractive, but distraught woman in her twenties, puffing a cigarette, eyes red and swollen from crying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian, seemingly reassured, opens the door for her.  She sees Marika, realizes she's upset about something, and feels immediately compassionate toward her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And she lets Marika in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Who is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's Marika.  Is Paula there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's at work.  I'm her mother.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh.  I thought today was Saturday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry.  I had a wretched night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh.  You need a cappuccino.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - A FEW MINUTES LATER They're sitting at the dining table, having coffee.  Marian is listening sympathetically to Marika's tale of woe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This makes Marika laugh even harder.  Marian's story seems to have assuaged her own grief in some parallel way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Disciple's MOTORCYCLES GROWL OFF SCREEN, interrupting their tete-a-tete. Marian and Marika both rise simultaneously from the table and amble over to the window together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They reach the window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: And there was this number on my phone bill that I didn't recognize.  Calls made at three and four in the morning.  So, I called the number ... and a woman answered.  And I ... I hung up. (leans forward) So, then I followed him.  Just like in the movies.  And I found out that he has a wife and a little girl living in Brooklyn.  We had been going together for almost a year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking her head in disgust) Men ... they're all the same. (beat) Our pastor in Sioux Falls was caught with his wife's sister.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (brightening) Really?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, it was such a big scandal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Poor man had to leave town. (Marika laughs) And I hear that other women came forward.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, you ought to come out to South Dakota some time and meet my son, Steve. He's single.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What does he do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's an organic farmer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (chuckling) Oh.  Well, that would be a ... change. (smiles warmly) Thank you, Mrs. Peterson.  You have a very reassuring voice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wish they wouldn't come and go in packs, then they wouldn't be so loud.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - MARIAN'S AND MARIKA'S P.O.V. The Disciples dismounting from their bikes below, shutting down their engines and removing their helmets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At the window, Marian and Marika standing side by side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian does a double-take and throws a backward glance at Marika.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian and Marika smile at each other.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I wonder what they do in there?  Don't they frighten you?  They all look so ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ... Manly?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, probably none of them had a mother like you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Marian's FOOT STEPS OFF THE CURB.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE - Marian crosses the street headed in the direction of the Satan's Disciples headquarters. The Disciple Prospect is sitting alone, guarding the line of parked Harleys.  He's wearing dark aviator shades and his trademark red bandana tied over his head.  Marian steps bravely right up to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Disciple Prospect removes his sunglasses and looks at her mock reprovingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian seems to accept the explanation.  She glances up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, sir. (the Disciple Prospect looks up, poker-faced) I just wanted to thank you for helping me get into my building yesterday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, sure, no problem, you're welcome.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My daughter lives across the street from you people and she tells me that you keep this area safe.  Is that true?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We like to think so, yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you don't deal drugs?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who told you we deal drugs?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm just concerned about my daughter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't have to worry.  She's going to be fine.  We're law-abiding citizens just like you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about yesterday?  Kicking that poor boy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mildly annoyed) That poor boy's a crack dealer from Alphabet City.  We do not allow his kind on this block.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - The black, forbidding door leading into the clubhouse with its painting of Death on a stylized Harley, gripping lightning bolts for handlebars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - looking at Marian looking up at the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Is there something else I can do for you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I'd love to see inside your club.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taken aback) You want to come inside?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, if you're not holding a meeting or anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - A FEW MOMENTS LATER The Disciple Prospect emerges from the club with the HEAD DISCIPLE, a gentle giant of a man with a long, flowing wispy beard and an old man's paunch.  They're muttering about something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Head Disciple glances over at Marian standing curbside, expectantly awaiting approval.  He sees that she's ingenuous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian, smiling, comes forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the three disappear inside.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Her daughter lives across the street and she was wondering ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's curious ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell ... (calling out to Marian) Come on in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pointing to the steps leading up to the door) You watch your step here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The hallway leading into the clubhouse is dark and gloomy. ROCK MUSIC assails them as they make their passage into the main room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - They reach the main room where about ten or so DISCIPLES are lounging about.  One has his nose in a book, The Road Less Traveled.  Another reads the Wall Street Journal.  Two others are seated at a card table, playing a game of poker.  Still another is sprawled on a couch, smoking a cigarette.  The walls are festooned with biker posters.  The place is a bit of a mess, but innocuous. The Head Disciple stands in the center of the room and addresses his clan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns to Marian, realizing he doesn't know her name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian blushes at their warm response to her unexpected appearance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laughter erupts.  Marian smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amiable laughter fills the room.  Marian laughs with them. She glances all around her, fascinated by this dungeon she had dreamed and fantasized about since she first arrived in New York.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, guys.  This here is, uh ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (meekly) Marian.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (booming voice) Marian!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi, Marian. Hey, Marian. Yo, Marian.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (explaining her visit) Marian's daughter lives across the street and she was a little worried about her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 Swear to God, lady, she's not here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 Hey, is she cute?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #3 Does she like motorcycles?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #4 Can she cook?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, this isn't so bad.  It looks like our kids' rooms when they were growing up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: S - of overflowing ashtrays, crushed beer cans, fast food wrappers balled up and strewn on tables.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - to Marian, her brow knitted thoughtfully in a schoolmarmish expression.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Could use some cleaning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: S - of several of the Disciples' FACES, turning to her in SLOW MOTION with mock baleful looks of disapprobation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: then ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - MONTAGE A MONTAGE, with abbreviated SCENES DISSOLVING one into another of Marian supervising a thorough, top-to-bottom cleaning of the clubhouse: One Disciple sprays Easy-Off in a blackened oven. Another empties ashtrays. Yet Another vacuums. Still others pick up wrappers from under the couch, while Marian wags a reproving finger at them. One Disciple tosses the contents of an ashtray under the couch while Marian isn't looking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - MONTAGE CONTINUING - LATER Marian in the kitchen, wearing the cut-off blue jeans insignia jacket of the Satan's Disciples, their colors emblazoned on the back.  She pops the top on a can of beer and pours some of it into a huge pot of chili she's stirring over a stove, while the Disciples sit patiently in the background at a bar awaiting the food. Marian tries a sip of the beer and some of the Disciples smile approvingly. A FEW MOMENTS LATER - Marian ladles chili into all of their bowls in a series of
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - STILL LATER All the Disciples are huddled around Marian in the middle of the clubhouse, as if she were the mother hen, arms folded across their chests, smiles creasing their faces, sated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian starts off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some of the Disciples exchange petulant looks, rolling their eyes at the request.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All the Disciples break into laughter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I'd better be going.  It was nice meeting all of you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 Thanks, Marian.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks, Marian.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 The food was outstanding.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, if we can do anything for you, Marian, you just let us know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turns, considers for a moment) Well, there is one thing. (beat, mildly scolding) At night, your motorcycles are so darn loud, I'm not getting much sleep.  Now, I'm going home in a few days, so ... could I ask you to keep them quiet?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mollifying) Well, we'll, uh, see what we can do, Marian.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A narrow, stand-alone ten-story isosceles-shaped office building, on an island of land in downtown Manhattan. ESTABLISHING SHOT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paula, with her mother in tow, knocks on an open office door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: an avuncular-looking man in his mid-forties rises from his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paula and Marian enter the office and halt mid-room across from his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paula and Mr. Palmer exchange disquieting glances.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paula is in a mild state of shock hearing her mother's fantastical anecdote.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . PALMER Come in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don, this is my mother. (turns to Marian) Mom, this is my boss, Don Palmer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (enthusiastically) Oh, it's so nice to meet you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . PALMER We're very glad to have your daughter working for us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (blurting out) I met the Satan's Disciples today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . PALMER (chuckling nervously) Really?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mother, I ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (waving her daughter off) My daughter lives right across the street from the Satan's Disciples' clubhouse, and I was so worried about her ... so, I went over and introduced myself. And they were the nicest people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . PALMER (playing along) Well, that's a very unusual New York experience.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I had a wonderful time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Paula is sitting at the dining table with a plate piled with roast chicken, potatoes, and broccoli in front of her.  She has a worried look etched on her face. Marian is in the kitchen in the background, feeling light and happy, a singsong quality to her voice.  She brings a plate of food for herself to the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian sits down at the table and takes a sip of her wine, picks up her utensils and gets ready to dig in.  She turns to Paula who isn't touching her food, her head in her hands. Marian, seemingly oblivious of her daughter's feelings, prattles on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian finally notices that Paula isn't listening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian retreats into herself, sips her wine - as if she, herself, now wonders if she's lost her mind - and her buoyant mood deflates almost at once.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian doesn't remember, and her daughter's words pierce her. She's afraid to object.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paula lays a reassuring hand on Marian's arm, talks to her condescendingly, as if she were a child.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian doesn't bother to argue, fearing anything she might say would compromise her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paula grips Marian's arm a little tighter and shakes it gently as if snapping her back to reality.  Marian returns her a tight-lipped smile.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: And they were so friendly those young men.  Though I do think they should shave their beards and ... and get some nicer clothes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you say ... we take a subway uptown and see a play tonight?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mom ... I mean, it's amusing to imagine such a thing, but ... how many of those pills have you been taking?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stung, taken aback) Oh, that has nothing to do with it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no, it's my fault.  I've been pushing you too hard to do things on your own.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The, um, other night, I got up to get a glass of water and you were standing by the window talking to daddy.  I called out to you, but you didn't answer.  You remember?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: New York is a ... it's a strange place in the summertime.  The noise, the warm air, it's ... easy to imagine things.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, you know you didn't go into the clubhouse, did you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's okay.  Dad's dying put a lot of stress on you.  But you're going to be all right.  We're all going to be all right.  Where did you get this vivid imagination, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Marian, lying supine on the convertible sofa bed by the open window, snoring peacefully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the sidewalk, the Disciple Prospect sits next to the fire breathing oil drum, standing sentry over the Harleys. One of the Disciples comes out of the clubhouse and they high five.  The Disciple mounts his Harley and is about to kick start it to life, when the Disciple Prospect rises from his stool.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Disciple about to start his bike, turns. The Disciple Prospect raises two fingers to his lips in a kind of warning, then gestures up to Paula's co-op where Marian is sleeping. The Disciple, remembering the new rule, nods assent with a slightly annoyed expression. Then, he puts his Harley into neutral, dismounts, and starts slowly walking it down the quiet, ill-lit street.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yo, man!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The room is cast in soft ambient light from the street. Paula comes into the living room and lies down next to her mother on the sofa bed and rouses her awake.  Marian swims leadenly back to consciousness. PAULA Mom, I need to talk to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian pats her daughter on the arm.  Paula pricks up her ears for a minute.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (still drowsy) If it's about the bikers, dear, I don't want to talk about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I had a dream about daddy.  Do you think I'll ever meet anyone like him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I hope so, dear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know that guy in the pictures you saw?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aaron?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah ... turned out to be a real jerk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's unusually quiet tonight, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mm hmm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A lovely, sun-drenched day.  Shadows dapple a promenade along one of the park's many ponds.  Paula and Marian walk arm-in arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They walk off into the golden light.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I think you should consider coming out and staying with me longer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I don't want to be in the way. You've got your career and everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You wouldn't be in the way.  I like having you around.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dear, I was thinking.  Why don't we go to Paris next year?  I've never been.  Your father, God bless him, wasn't much for traveling.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd love to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Marian is finishing up her packing.  Paula comes from the kitchen, bearing a gift for her mother to take home with her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paula extends her arms and embraces her mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paula blows her mother a kiss and Marian throws her daughter a little wave.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Here you go. (Marian accepts the gift) I think you should talk to Dr. Byrne when you get back about how much Valium he's prescribing.  Okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At my age, I'm going to take any pill that makes me feel better.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mother!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can make my own decisions.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I love you, Mom. (turns to leave) I have to run.  You remembered to call the limousine service, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mm hmm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pulling on her backpack) Well, bye.  And have a safe trip ... and ... Paris in the spring!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pensive) Goodbye, sweetheart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Marian steps down the stairs of her daughter's building.  A smile breaks out on her face when she SEES:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - of idling Harleys in the middle of the street, waiting for her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - turns to the Head Disciple, materializing behind her, carrying her luggage.  He gestures with his head toward the motorcycles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - The Disciple Prospect takes Marian's luggage from the Head Disciple and hauls it over to one of the waiting Harleys and straps it on to the carrying rack. Then, he helps Marian onto the back of the Harley she's going to be riding to the airport.  Gently, he places a helmet - festooned with decals of fire-breathing reptiles - over her head and affixes the chin-strap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marian nods and beams at the same time. The other Harleys form a circle around Marian's motorcycle. The Disciple Prospect gives them a signal and they start off, one by one, forming a V-shaped procession. Marian, completely comfortable on her motorcycle, her arms around her Disciple escort, her fever dream now manifest.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: All right?
dialogue.name: dialogue
